Mathematical chess problem wiki Mathematical_chess_problem Mathematical chess problem and Solving chess wiki Solving_chess Solving chess
The game structure and nature of chess are related to several branches of mathematics

Many combinatorical wiki Combinatorics Combinatorics and topological wiki Topology Topology problems connected to chess such as the knight s tour wiki Knight 27s_tour Knight s tour and the eight queens puzzle wiki Eight_queens_puzzle Eight queens puzzle have been known for hundreds of years

upload wikimedia org wikipedia commons thumb 8 86 Knight 27s_tour svg 180px-Knight 27s_tour svg png wiki File Knight 27s_tour svg Mathematicians Euler wiki Euler Euler Legendre wiki Adrien-Marie_Legendre Adrien-Marie Legendre de Moivre wiki De_Moivre De Moivre and Vandermonde wiki Vandermonde Vandermonde studied the knight s tour wiki Knight 27s_tour Knight s tour

The number of legal positions in chess is estimated to be 4 59 0 38 1044 with a 95 confidence level 141 with a game-tree complexity wiki Game-tree_complexity Game-tree complexity of approximately 10123
The game-tree complexity of chess was first calculated by Claude Shannon wiki Claude_Shannon Claude Shannon as 10120 a number known as the Shannon number wiki Shannon_number Shannon number 142

An average position typically has thirty to forty possible moves but there may be as few as zero in the case of checkmate or stalemate or in a constructed position as many as 218 143 In 1913 Ernst Zermelo wiki Ernst_Zermelo Ernst Zermelo used chess as a basis for his theory of game strategies which is considered one of the predecessors of game theory wiki Game_theory Game theory 144

Zermelo s theorem wiki Zermelo 27s_theorem_ game_theory Zermelo s theorem game theory states that it is possible to solve chess wiki Solving_chess Solving chess i e to determine with certainty the outcome of a perfectly played game either White can force a win or Black can force a win or both sides can force at least a draw 145 With 1043 legal positions in chess however it will take an impossibly long time to compute a perfect strategy with any feasible technology 146 Psychology There is an extensive scientific literature on chess psychology note 6 148 149 150 151
Alfred Binet wiki Alfred_Binet Alfred Binet and others showed that knowledge wiki Knowledge Knowledge and verbal rather than visuospatial ability lies at the core of expertise 152 153
In his doctoral thesis Adriaan de Groot wiki Adriaan_de_Groot Adriaan de Groot showed that chess masters can rapidly perceive the key features of a position 154
According to de Groot this perception wiki Perception Perception made possible by years of practice and study is more important than the sheer ability to anticipate moves
De Groot showed that chess masters can memorize positions shown for a few seconds almost perfectly

The ability to memorize does not alone account for chess-playing skill since masters and novices when faced with random arrangements of chess pieces had equivalent recall about six positions in each case
Rather it is the ability to recognize patterns which are then memorized which distinguished the skilled players from the novices

When the positions of the pieces were taken from an actual game the masters had almost total positional recall 155 More recent research has focused on chess as mental training wiki Chess_as_mental_training Chess as mental training the respective roles of knowledge and look-ahead search brain imaging wiki Brain_imaging Brain imaging studies of chess masters and novices blindfold chess wiki Blindfold_chess Blindfold chess the role of personality wiki Personality_psychology Personality psychology and intelligence wiki Intelligence Intelligence in chess skill gender differences and computational models of chess expertise
The role of practice and talent in the development of chess and other domains of expertise has led to much empirical investigation
Ericsson and colleagues have argued that deliberate practice is sufficient for reaching high levels of expertise in chess 156
Recent research however fails to replicate their results and indicates that factors other than practice are also important 157 158

For example Fernand Gobet wiki Fernand_Gobet Fernand Gobet and colleagues have shown that stronger players started playing chess at a young age and that experts born in the Northern Hemisphere are more likely to have been born in late winter and early spring

Compared to the general population chess players are more likely to be non-right-handed though they found no correlation between handedness and skill 158 A relationship between chess skill and intelligence has long been discussed in scientific literature as well as in popular culture
Academic studies that investigate the relationship date back at least to 1927 159
Although one meta-analysis and most children studies find a positive correlation between general cognitive ability and chess skill adult studies show mixed results 160 161 Composition Richard Réti _

There are many types of chess problems the two most important are _
Directmates wiki Glossary_of_chess_problems directmate Glossary of chess problems
_ White to move first and checkmate Black within a specified number of moves against any defense
These are often referred to as mate in _n_ for example mate in three a _three-mover_ two- and three-move problems are the most common
These usually involve positions that would be highly unlikely to occur in an actual game and are intended to illustrate a particular _
theme wiki Glossary_of_chess_problems theme Glossary of chess problems _ usually requiring a surprising or counterintuitive _
key wiki Glossary_of_chess_problems key Glossary of chess problems _ move
Themes associated with chess problems occasionally appear in actual games when they are referred to as problem-like moves 164 _
Studies wiki Endgame_study Endgame study _ orthodox problems where the stipulation is that White to play must win or draw
The majority of studies are endgame wiki Chess_endgame

sections.text: The chess machine is an ideal one to start with since 1 the problem is sharply defined both in allowed operations the moves and in the ultimate goal checkmate 2 it is neither so simple as to be trivial nor too difficult for satisfactory solution 3 chess is generally considered to require thinking for skillful play a solution of this problem will force us either to admit the possibility of a mechanized thinking or to further restrict our concept of thinking 4 the discrete structure of chess fits well into the digital nature of modern computers 176
